name: Zine Lab
description:
Zines have long been spaces for reflection, resistance and reclaiming stories. In this workshop with writer-illustrator Preston Olakatu, explore zine-making as a creative act of self-expression — one that holds space for personal narratives, queerness and community.

The workshop will begin with a short presentation covering the history and cultural significance of zines, tracing their roots from punk and feminist movements to present-day DIY publishing. 

With an emphasis on experimentation, create your own zine exploring different formats while learning techniques such as layering, sequencing and layout structure.

name: A Chaap for Everyone
description:
Create your own chaap or label inspired by your personal or social experience of exclusion and challenge common stereotypes creatively. This workshop led by Sparsh encourages you to think about how objects, visuals and stories can foster belonging or alienation, to promote a more thoughtful, inclusive approach to design. Participants will also be given a guided walkthrough of the Ticket, Tika, Chaap exhibition currently open to visitors at MAP. 

If you would like to bring your own device to design digitally, you are free to do so. Materials will be provided if you would like to design on paper.

name: A World of Many Loves: 'Polyamory In India'
description: Curious about what lies beyond traditional monogamy? Drop in for a talk helmed by author Arundhati Ghosh about her latest book, 'All our loves' in conversation with Anita Cheria. Try your hand at relationship roleplaying games, to discover the emotional joys, challenges, and questions around loving more than one person at a time.

name: Memory Keepers: A guide to photo conservation
description:
We've all been there, finding that old family photo tucked away in a drawer, only to discover it's starting to fade, crack, or yellow. Those irreplaceable moments with loved ones, and memories captured are slowly disappearing.
The truth is, photographs are fragile. Heat, humidity, light, and even the way we store them can cause damage that sometimes can't be undone. But here's the good news, you don't need to be a professional to protect your photo collection!

In this talk, Chloe Lucas, a professional conservator will inform us of some preventive conservation actions that can be easily taken and implemented in a personal and private context to improve the long-term preservation of private photographic collections.

name: Up, Close and Centre
description:
Ever admired the vibrant mural outside MAP? This is the work of Bhuri Bai, an extraordinary artist from Madhya Pradesh. She was not only the first artist from her community to work on paper and canvas using synthetic paints but she also brought Pithora art to global recognition.

This month’s edition of Up, Close and Center will feature Soumyadeep Dasgupta, an Education Officer from the MAP team. He looks at Padmashree Bhuri Bai’s work from our permanent exhibition VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection.

Up, Close & Centre is a series to help delve deeper into the context, narratives and makings of one artwork from our collection or ongoing exhibition, chosen by our team members.
